text: I have always felt in my core that I
wanted to be an actress always but I
never thought about films when I was a
kid I didn't we didn't get our first VCR
until I was 13 and we had three TV
channels and I remember being taken to
the movies maybe four times by either
one of my parents as a kid that we just
didn't have very much money so I didn't
really understand the concept of being
an act an actor and actress in films it
was something that Judy Garland did and
so I always thought that if I was lucky
enough for it to work out I would I'd be
on the stage and actually when I got was
cast in an episode one episode of a TV
series in England when I was 16 my god
that was a huge deal that was a huge
deal an episode of a TV series and it
paid me equity minimum which and that
was a lot of money for me in those days
and how I began though even though I was
16 being cast you know this small
partners TV series and the year later I
was cast in heavenly creatures which was
the first film I ever did prior to that
you know I'd been I'd been auditioning a
lot between the age of about 12 and 15
and I never got the parts never and
actually more often than not because my
name began with the W I would be at the
back of the queue and they would just
run out of time so everyone from kind of
T onwards would just be sent home and
you wouldn't even get a look in and I
was always wearing the wrong clothes my
hair had always got static it's just in
the moment when you really didn't want
it to have static I never had any makeup
because there was never any money for
makeup and even if I had done it I would
have stolen my mother's or full sort of
plum from the body shop that would have
been smushed by both my other two
sisters by then
and so but also I was as a kid I was I
was bullied at school because I was
always quite chubby I was always
overweight and I was always told I was
wrong I was doing the wrong thing I was
sort of made to feel ashamed of myself
my appearance everything about myself
the slowest runner I was just everything
was wrong and you know you develop a
sort of a self-preservation muscle when
you experience something like that but I
did always love acting and I would
always feel quite smug about the fact
that I had this one thing that I really
loved and I didn't have to go anywhere
or do anything to be able to do it
I could literally close my bedroom door
and just go on ahead and do it in the
mirror talk about like for hours at a
time I could practice making myself cry
I could practice doing on-screen
make-out sessions I could just do it and
and I knew that nobody else in my class
at school had any understanding of how
great that feeling was and that honestly
is something that I have always hung on
to no matter what and it's of that that
love that just genuinely pure love is
something that has affected sometimes
the choices that I've made you know for
example after Titanic which was so huge
and overwhelming and and and I you know
I thought I was handling it all fine I
know I'm fine I know what I'm doing of
course my life's not gonna change my
life's not changing my life was
completely upside-down and I actually
didn't know who the hell I was and and
was not remotely equipped to be a famous
person I didn't know what to do or how
to cope at all and in actual fact that
was when the determination to choose the
things that I really loved and really
believed in above and beyond everything
else that is when that really began
because it meant that I could preserve
my love of acting and I figured if I
always loved it then I'll always be able
to do it honestly and with a open heart
and so that's what I would say to you
and also never ever ever give up because
I was the kid who watched Whoopi
Goldberg hosting the Academy Awards at
the age of God knows whatever I was
I remember at the end of the show
looking out to the TV audience and
saying of all those kids out there who
wonder if one day they could be in this
room well you know that could be you I
was that kid watching going oh my god
what could be me and look I've been
there five times
you
